p: There is reasonable consensus that fruit bats are reservoirs for Ebola and Marburg, while the multimammate rat carries Lassa. Outbreaks of Ebola and Marburg have generally involved hunting and butchering non-human primates, which, like humans, can become hosts for the virus. However, there have been cases of infection through handling other dead animals including antelopes and porcupines. 8 In the case of Lassa, transmission tends to occur through touching surfaces contaminated with rodent saliva or excreta (Mills 2005; Stephenson et al. 1984; Ter Meulen et al. 1996). All three diseases can pass between humans through contact with bodily fluids or contaminated objects. 9 However, many details of transmission cycles, including the varying contributions of hosts and vectors to the rate of pathogenic spread, remain unknown (Hugot et al. 2001; Wolfe et al. 2005).
